TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi beforefieldinit DynamicDataRoute extends System.Web.Routing.Route

Docs.summary: Represents a route that is used by ASP.NET Dynamic Data.

remarks.format:
## Remarks You use routes to configure Dynamic Data behavior.
The static <xref:System.Web.Routing.RouteTable.Routes%2A> property of the <xref:System.Web.Routing.RouteTable> type holds a collection of routes. For Dynamic Data, one or more routes are typically registered (added to the <xref:System.Web.Routing.RouteTable.Routes%2A> property) in the `Application_Start` event in the Global.asax file. For example, routes determine whether the details for a row of data should be shown on the same page as the list of rows. They can also determine whether details should appear on the same page as the list of rows for some tables but not others.
You set the <xref:System.Web.DynamicData.DynamicDataRoute.Action%2A>, <xref:System.Web.DynamicData.DynamicDataRoute.ViewName%2A>, <xref:System.Web.DynamicData.DynamicDataRoute.Table%2A>, and <xref:System.Web.DynamicData.DynamicDataRoute.Model%2A> properties and provide a pattern for the URL in the <xref:System.Web.Routing.Route.%23ctor%2A> constructor.
Dynamic Data uses the URL pattern that you provide to match URL patterns for requests and to create URLs. For more information, see <xref:System.Web.DynamicData.DynamicDataRoute.%23ctor%2A>.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig specialname rtspecialname instance void .ctor(string url) cil managed

Docs.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class by using the specified URL pattern.

remarks.format:
## Remarks Typically, you specify the URLs that Dynamic Data will create by using substitution parameters. For example, if you pass the string "{table}/{action}", the result would be the URL "~/Products/ListDetails.aspx" when you view the Product table by using the ListDetails action.
Using substitution parameters is not required. You could pass the string "Table/DynamicData", which would produce "\~/Table/DynamicData.aspx". You could pass "MyPageName" to produce "\~/MyPageName.aspx". Dynamic Data does not rely on the URL to determine table and action information.

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the name of an action for a route.
Docs.value: The action name for a route.

remarks.format: ## Remarks For a list of possible action names, see <xref:System.Web.DynamicData.PageAction?displayProperty=nameWithType>. If you do not set this property when you create an instance of <xref:System.Web.DynamicData.DynamicDataRoute>, the route will apply to all actions.

Docs.summary: Returns the action from the object for the current Dynamic Data Web request.
Docs.returns: The action. For a list of possible values, see .
Docs.exception: The action was not found in the Web request routing information.

Docs.summary: Returns routing information for a specific Web request.
Docs.returns: The routing information for the Web request.

remarks.format: ## Remarks The `httpContext` parameter provides Web request information that is required so that the requested table and action can be identified.

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the data model to which the route applies.
Docs.value: The data-model metadata that the route applies to.

remarks.format: ## Remarks If you do not set this property when you create an instance of <xref:System.Web.DynamicData.DynamicDataRoute>, the default model for the registered <xref:System.Data.Linq.DataContext> instance is used.

MemberSignature.Value: public: property System::Web::DynamicData::DynamicDataRouteHandler ^ RouteHandler { System::Web::DynamicData::DynamicDataRouteHandler ^ get(); void set(System::Web::DynamicData::DynamicDataRouteHandler ^ value); };

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the object that processes requests for the route.
Docs.value: The handler that is used to process requests for the route.

remarks.format: ## Remarks The <xref:System.Web.DynamicData.DynamicDataRoute.RouteHandler%2A> property is identical to the <xref:System.Web.Routing.Route.RouteHandler%2A?displayProperty=nameWithType> property. It is provided as a strongly typed version of the <xref:System.Web.Routing.Route.RouteHandler%2A?displayProperty=nameWithType> property for coding convenience.

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the name of the table for the route.
Docs.value: The name of the table that is associated with the route.

remarks.format: ## Remarks If you do not set this property when you create an instance of <xref:System.Web.DynamicData.DynamicDataRoute>, the route will apply to all tables in the data model that are indicated by <xref:System.Web.DynamicData.DynamicDataRoute.Model%2A>.

Attribute.AttributeName: get: System.Runtime.TargetedPatchingOptOut("Performance critical to inline this type of method across NGen image boundaries")
set: System.Runtime.TargetedPatchingOptOut("Performance critical to inline this type of method across NGen image boundaries")

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the name of the .aspx page that is associated with a route.
Docs.value: The name of the .aspx page that is associated with the route. If no page is specified for the route, the property returns the value of the property with ".aspx" appended to it.

remarks.format: ## Remarks Dynamic data uses several standard .aspx page names to create the UI to let users view, update, and delete data from a given table. These page names include List.aspx, Details.aspx, Edit.aspx, Insert.aspx, and ListDetails.aspx. The <xref:System.Web.DynamicData.DynamicDataRoute.ViewName%2A> property specifies which of these pages should be used for a given table and action.
